chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should aim to make presidential outcomes track the national vote more closely while keeping elections administered by states and results easy to audit and accept. A workable compromise is to keep the Electoral College but replace winner-take-all with a uniform proportional split of electors tied to the statewide vote, while also adopting a small set of national baseline rules for voter access, ballot counting, post‑election audits, and automatic recounts in close margins. For states that prefer a faster path toward popular-vote alignment, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact can serve as an optional bridge once broad participation is reached.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Presidential elections should be transparent, auditable, and consistent enough that the outcome is broadly accepted even in close races. A practical consensus reform is to keep state-run administration and the Electoral College framework, but end winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally (with electors bound to the voters’ result), so more votes matter in every state and campaigns compete beyond a few battlegrounds. Pair this with clear national baseline standards for ballot access and design, secure counting, post‑election audits, and automatic recount triggers to reduce disputes and strengthen legitimacy. Where feasible, a ranked-choice or runoff-style backstop can help ensure the winner has broad support and reduce spoiler fears.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Presidential elections should be easy to understand, consistent across states, and verifiable—so every lawful vote is counted and people can trust the result even when their side loses. A practical compromise is to keep the state-based Electoral College but end winner-take-all by awarding electors proportionally (or by districts with strong anti-gerrymandering safeguards) and requiring electors to follow the voters. Pair that with clear national baseline standards for ballot access, paper-based audits, and automatic recount triggers in close races, so campaigns have incentives to compete in more places while smaller and rural communities still retain a meaningful voice.
